message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about sustainability and reducing waste. Buying permanent things instead of disposable things is an example of conservation, as it helps to preserve and protect resources by reducing the amount of waste generated. Option (A) is incorrect because composting refers to the process of breaking down organic material into nutrient-rich soil. Option (C) is incorrect because recycling refers to the process of converting waste materials into new products. Option (D) is incorrect because returning typically refers to returning items to a store for a refund or exchange, and is not related to sustainability efforts.

This question requires basic knowledge about environmental sustainability and consumer choices. Buying permanent things instead of disposable things is an act of conservation because it reduces waste and the consumption of resources. Option (A) is incorrect because composting refers to the process of decomposing organic matter. Option (C) refers to the process of reusing materials to create new products, which is different from the concept of buying permanent things. Option (D) is unrelated to the context of the question.

This question requires an understanding of the concept of sustainability and making choices that reduce waste. Buying permanent things instead of disposable things is an example of conservation because it involves conserving resources and reducing waste. Option (A) is incorrect because composting refers to the process of decomposing organic matter. Option (C) is incorrect because recycling involves the conversion of waste materials into new products. Option (D) is incorrect because returning refers to the act of bringing something back to a place of purchase.
